As the silent craft passes through the upper atmosphere, its acting-
commander, Gatara, sits rather uncomfortably in the navigator's 
seat.  It isn't that the chair is poorly designed - it's just that 
she's much too big for it.  Usually the giant Rogue works in the 
engine room, where her size is less of a hinderance and more of an 
asset.  But given the lack of able-bodied crew, she's needed on the 
bridge.

"See any good landing spots yet, folks?" she asks the other two 
Rogues in the room.

"Nothing worth mentioning," Torin remarks from the piloting station.  
"Looks to me like a matter of personal preference."

"How about there?"  Jayde points out an area in the southernmost part 
of the mountains.  (Unknown to them just yet, this is within easy 
travelling distance of the Predacon base.)  It's a rather comical 
sight, because Jayde is the smallest Rogue, and looks much like a 
toddler compared to the 12' Gatara.

"Worth a shot," Torin sighs.  "It's sheltered, out of the way - and 
Riekan just informed me over the comm that the engines are gonna quit 
on us soon."

Gatara is momentarily irritated that Riekan didn't page HER with that 
message, but given the situation, she's willing to forgive it this 
time.  "Do it," she orders.

--- In nbwrpg@y..., "cardhead649" <cardhead649@y...> wrote:
> The damage report was not encouraging.  Although its quarry had 
> escaped the energy storm's wrath, Rogue Star had not.  Now most of 
> its crew was in a comatose state, and repairs were sorely needed.  
> After examining the situation, the conscious Rogues chose to land 
on 
> the most suitable landmass - the large northern continent.  And so 
> the Rogue Star, hidden under its powerful cloaking device, began to 
> descend ...
> 
> Meanwhile, in the storage room that doubled as her sleeping 
quarters, 
> another transformer was busy moping.  There wasn't much else to 
do.  
> A prisoner by another name, Phoenix hated the Rogues and all that 
> they stood for, but was too terrified to do anything about it.  
She'd 
> been conditioned over the course of nine stellar cycles to cower 
away 
> from them.
> 
> Not to mention, she hated violence in any form even more than she 
> despised her captors.  Phoenix had no idea where her strong beliefs 
> came from, but she knew it had to have something to do with the 
> memory engrams the Rogues had destroyed before her eyes, in the 
> earliest event she could recall clearly.
